fields.tagline: "What the hell am I doing here?"
fields.summary: Wherein I try to justify/explain the countless hours I've poured into getting this personal website off the ground. Includes a short description of the journey and technology behind it, and describes the expectations I've set for myself at this very early stage.
fields.content:
[{"id": "4eaf4b81-ac26-4ca8-9e51-d2624c9bc4ac", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

Actually I decided to start a blog sometime late in the 20th century. And here it is! First I spend 2.5 decades as a web developer, working out what I need to know, and then finally found the time. This whole dammed \"web\" thing kept evolving and moving the goal posts, ya know?

Why am I here?

Many reasons.

  • I'm always learning new things, and spending all my time split between official documentation, books, ChatGPT, and StackOverflow, because there are no good tutorials or guides anywhere on the internet (that I can find), and I'm driven to close those gaps
  • Having your very own web presence felt like a cool idea to me in 1997, and I never lost that feeling. Skip to today, with centralised social media hastening the downfall of civilisation, it's not just cool it's literally revolutionary!
  • To earn a modicum of credibility as a developer/person/potential employee \u2013 and especially to feel confident calling myself a \"full stack\" developer \u2013 writing a front-end, a back-end, a DevOps pipeline, running it all in production yourself feels good
  • Now I have one repository that's also a rapid-development platform, which I can keep up-to-date with tooling, where I can experiment with whatever I want while not having to worry about bootstrapping new projects all the time\u00a0\u2013\u00a0\"feature\" branches, ftw!

What do I plan to write about?

Mostly I'm planning on writing up technical guides, recipes, tutorials, and what-have-yous, just based on whatever I've been learning or working with lately \u2013 but only when there isn't already a wealth of Googleable stuff out there already.

But this is my blog, and I'll be dammed if I'm going to hold myself back from the temptation to opine about whatever's going on in the world or my life. Maybe reviews of books and movies? I just like writing! You won't find a skerrick of \"AI generated\" content here.

What is it made of?

I took the best damn CMS framework in the world (Wagtail), written on top of the best dammed web framework in the world (Django), and wrote a CMS & blog application generic enough that I eventually split it out into a package called Picata. The goal is to develop Picata into a CMS solution others might find useful, since as wonderful as Wagtail is it does require weeks-to-months of full-stack developer time to turn it into a nice and working website, the the offerings for pre-built solutions are currently scarce.

You'll find more details between the Picata docs and the repo for this site itself.

I learned a lot of interesting modern stuff along the way, but TailwindCSS deserves a special mention for all the front-end styling you see before you; I found it utterly game-changing when it comes to rapidly generating pretty, concise, responsive CSS. It even made it easy to write themes you can change between (with those buttons in the top-right corner), and I could still do it all in Sass! (Mmmm, semantic whitespace.)

"}]

fields.tagline: Just is a beautiful solution to the problems lurking within the fraught problem-realm known to computer scientists as "running stuff"
fields.summary: Just is basically a command-runner. After decades of using other standard (but in retrospect ad-hoc methods), I've settled comfortably into writing just one Justfile, at the root of any given project, for the vast majority of "shell-scripty" stuff (aka the glue) required to get anything useful done.
fields.content:
[{"id": "cb48d52a-4faf-4e72-8c66-a44a91f1d564", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

Just is basically a command-runner, and a great blessing in my life. What have I done to \"just run commands\" in the past? I took a relatively standard-looking journey through the problem of \"running stuff\", which vaguely went:

  • Excessive use of man pages to remember arguments and flags
  • Abusive grepping of a shell's history to see what I'd done before
  • A Constant addition of aliases and functions to my shell via startup files
  • Pipenv [scripts], npm \"scripts\", other and other tool-spcific stuff
  • Make? CMake?!
  • Maybe just a bunch of .sh files under a scripts/ directory?
"}]

fields.tagline: How I learned to stop worrying and love `repo: local`
fields.summary: [Talk about how you gave up on the mypy pre-commit hook and used local, because of how pre-commit creates a new virtualenv for each hook – and additional_dependencies would have required most of the project to be declared! … but Ruff, being static, runs just fine.

fields.tagline: The "everything everywhere all at once" guide to deploying Django in the cloud
fields.summary: A step-by-step guide to deploy a Django app, for both development and production servers, to a single server in the cloud – using OpenTofu (a fork of Terraform), targeting DigitalOcean, utilising Just to manage the shell-scripting glue, and a hell of a lot of cloud-init.

fields.top_content:
[{"id": "2feced3d-03b3-4be0-8041-03372f10a51f", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

About me

Welcome! I'm a software developer from Perth, Western Australia, who's mostly worked with full web stacks, but generally love all things Python, and many things DevOps.

This is my blog / personal website / little, decentralised, hand-rolled place on the internet where I can post and rant.

fields.object_str: So I decided to start a blog

content.title: So I decided to start a blog
content.content:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

So I decided to start a blog

Actually I decided to start a blog sometime late in the 20th century. And here it is! First I spend 2.5 decades as a web developer, working out what I need to know, and then finally found the time. This whole dammed \"web\" thing kept evolving and moving the goal posts\u2026 you understand.

", "id": "4eaf4b81-ac26-4ca8-9e51-d2624c9bc4ac"}]
content.summary: Wherein I try to justify and/or explain the countless hours I've poured into getting this personal website off the ground.
content.tagline: What the hell am I doing here?
content.draft_title: So I decided to start a blog

content.search_description: I'm a software developer from Perth, Australia, who loves most things Python. This is my little hand-crafted blog-cum-personal website-cum-little decentralised rant-hole on the internet.

content.title: Just using a Justfile
content.content:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Just is basically a command-runner, and a great blessing in my life. What have I done to \"just run commands\" in the past? I took a relatively standard-looking journey through the problem of \"running stuff\", which vaguely went:

  • Excessive use of man pages to remember arguments and flags
  • Abusive grepping of a shell's history to see what I'd done before
  • A Constant addition of aliases and functions to my shell via startup files
  • Pipenv [scripts], npm \"scripts\", other and other tool-spcific stuff
  • Make? CMake?!
  • Maybe just a bunch of .sh files under a scripts/ directory?
", "id": "cb48d52a-4faf-4e72-8c66-a44a91f1d564"}]
content.summary: Just is basically a command-runner. After decades of using other standard (but in retrospect ad-hoc methods), I've settled comfortably into writing just one Justfile, at the root of any given project, for the vast majority of "shell-scripty" stuff (aka the glue) required to get anything useful done.
content.tagline: Just is a beautiful solution to the problems lurking within the fraught problem-realm known to computer scientists as "running stuff"

content.title: pre-commit, Python types & virtual envs
content.summary: [Talk about how you gave up on the mypy pre-commit hook and used local, because of how pre-commit creates a new virtualenv for each hook – and additional_dependencies would have required most of the project to be declared! … but Ruff, being static, runs just fine.
content.tagline: How I learned to stop worrying and love `repo: local`

content.title: Deploying Django all at once
content.summary: A step-by-step guide to deploy a Django app, for both development and production servers, to a single server in the cloud – using OpenTofu (a fork of Terraform), targeting DigitalOcean, utilising Just to manage the shell-scripting glue, and a hell of a lot of cloud-init.
content.tagline: The "everything everywhere all at once" guide to deploying Django in the cloud

[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Actually I decided to start a blog sometime late in the 20th century. And here it is! First I spend 2.5 decades as a web developer, working out what I need to know, and then finally found the time. This whole dammed \"web\" thing kept evolving and moving the goal posts, ya know?

Why am I here?

Many reasons.

  • I'm always learning new things, and spending all my time split between official documentation, books, ChatGPT, and StackOverflow, because there are no good tutorials or guides anywhere on the internet (that I can find), and I'm driven to close those gaps
  • Having your very own web presence felt like a cool idea to me in 1997, and I never lost that feeling. Skip to today, with centralised social media hastening the downfall of civilisation, it's not just cool it's literally revolutionary!
  • To earn a modicum of credibility as a developer/person/potential employee \u2013 and especially to feel confident calling myself a \"full stack\" developer \u2013 writing a front-end, a back-end, a DevOps pipeline, running it all in production yourself feels good
  • Now I have one repository that's also a rapid-development platform, which I can keep up-to-date with tooling, where I can experiment with whatever I want while not having to worry about bootstrapping new projects all the time\u00a0\u2013\u00a0\"feature\" branches, ftw!

What do I plan to write about?

Mostly I'm planning on writing up technical guides, recipes, tutorials, and what-have-yous, just based on whatever I've been learning or working with lately \u2013 but only when there isn't already a wealth of Googleable stuff out there already.

But this is my blog, and I'll be dammed if I'm going to hold myself back from the temptation to opine about whatever's going on in the world or my life. Maybe reviews of books and movies? I just like writing! You won't find a skerrick of \"AI generated\" content here.

What is it made of?

I took the best damn CMS framework in the world (Wagtail), written on top of the best dammed web framework in the world (Django), and wrote a CMS & blog application generic enough that I eventually split it out into a package called Picata. The goal is to develop Picata into a CMS solution others might find useful, since as wonderful as Wagtail is it does require weeks-to-months of full-stack developer time to turn it into a nice and working website, the the offerings for pre-built solutions are currently scarce.

You'll find more details between the Picata docs and the repo for this site itself.

I learned a lot of interesting modern stuff along the way, but TailwindCSS deserves a special mention for all the front-end styling you see before you; I found it utterly game-changing when it comes to rapidly generating pretty, concise, responsive CSS. It even made it easy to write themes you can change between (with those buttons in the top-right corner), and I could still do it all in Sass! (Mmmm, semantic whitespace.)

", "id": "4eaf4b81-ac26-4ca8-9e51-d2624c9bc4ac"}]
content.summary: Wherein I try to justify/explain the countless hours I've poured into getting this personal website off the ground. Includes a short description of the journey and technology behind it, and describes the expectations I've set for myself at this very early stage.
content.tagline: "What the hell am I doing here?"
content.draft_title: So I decided to start a blog

fields.label: Welcome to your new Wagtail site!
